problem.p:
An experienced skier knows how to gain speed while skiing over a small dip in the snow. The trick is to jump in the air and land smoothly on the downward slope.
Here a skier traveling at velocity v wants to jump up and smoothly land on a dip that makes an angle b with the horizontal. For what distance d back from the dip should the skier jump up into the air in order to make a smooth landing? Assume that the skis have no friction with the snow.
Use g for the gravitational constant.
Tip: be sure to write trigonometric functions in the form sin(b) or tan(b).
